Journal.Title: The journal of physical chemistry. A

Article.ArticleTitle: Computational Investigation of RO<sub>2</sub> + HO<sub>2</sub> and RO<sub>2</sub> + RO<sub>2</sub> Reactions of Monoterpene Derived First-Generation Peroxy Radicals Leading to Radical Recycling.

AbstractText: The oxidation of biogenically emitted volatile organic compounds (BVOC) plays an important role in the formation of secondary organic aerosols (SOA) in the atmosphere. Peroxy radicals (RO<sub>2</sub>) are central intermediates in the BVOC oxidation process. Under clean (low-NO <sub>x</sub>) conditions, the main bimolecular sink reactions for RO<sub>2</sub> are with the hydroperoxy radical (HO<sub>2</sub>) and with other RO<sub>2</sub> radicals. Especially for small RO<sub>2</sub>, the RO<sub>2</sub> + HO<sub>2</sub> reaction mainly leads to closed-shell hydroperoxide products. However, there exist other known RO<sub>2</sub> + HO<sub>2</sub> and RO<sub>2</sub> + RO<sub>2</sub> reaction channels that can recycle radicals and oxidants in the atmosphere, potentially leading to lower-volatility products and enhancing SOA formation. In this work, we present a thermodynamic overview of two such reactions: (a) RO<sub>2</sub> + HO<sub>2</sub> → RO + OH + O<sub>2</sub> and (b) R'O<sub>2</sub> + RO<sub>2</sub> → R'O + RO + O<sub>2</sub> for selected monoterpene + oxidant derived peroxy radicals. The monoterpenes considered are α-pinene, β-pinene, limonene, trans-β-ocimene, and Δ<sup>3</sup>-carene. The oxidants considered are the hydroxyl radical (OH), the nitrate radical (NO<sub>3</sub>), and ozone (O<sub>3</sub>). The reaction Gibbs energies were calculated at the DLPNO-CCSD(T)/def2-QZVPP//ωB97X-D/aug-cc-pVTZ level of theory. All reactions studied here were found to be exergonic in terms of Gibbs energy. On the basis of a comparison with previous mechanistic studies, we predict that reaction a and reaction b are likely to be most important for first-generation peroxy radicals from O<sub>3</sub> oxidation (especially for β-pinene), while being less so for most first-generation peroxy radicals from OH and NO<sub>3</sub> oxidation. This is because both reactions are comparatively more exergonic for the O<sub>3</sub> oxidized systems than their OH and NO<sub>3</sub> oxidized counterparts. Our results indicate that bimolecular reactions of certain complex RO<sub>2</sub> may contribute to an increase in radical and oxidant recycling under high HO<sub>2</sub> conditions in the atmosphere, which can potentially enhance SOA formation.
